SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES,
No. 5
Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Graham)

Please print name and address in capital letters.
Your full name: Robert Charles Sanderson
Present Address: 4314 Valle Vista, San Diego, Calif., U.S.A.
Pioneer Address: Indian Head
Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1882 (came to Winnipeg) in 1873

(Throughout the questionnaires, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:
Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? Half a dozen. How many of these were bachelor's homes? All but 1.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Hardly ever in summer, about every two weeks in winter.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Week days in winter.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? All done without an invitation.

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Afternoon or evening.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? In the old days you always played invited or not. Anyone coming was always put up over the next day of a stranger.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) You did not ask them to stay nor did they ask to play. It was taken for granted by both parties.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? None except at meal time.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? Each of the family went where they liked best.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? No.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe. There were lots of dances in homes. You could go to two or three each week.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years how many times were you invited to visit your neighbors? How often did you visit their homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors' homes?

3. Did you usually visit on Sundays or other days?

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

What time of the day did you go? In the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to watch after the children?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, twice a month, etc.?
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

In 1884-85-86 in a school near us we had debates, songs, concerts regularly all winter.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

The schools were used for concerts, parties etc. to raise money for church support and to have a good time.

9. When was your first community hall built? One in town in 1884.

What material was it made of? Wood

How large was it? About 30 x 60

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? The town of Indian Head.

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? In village.

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.) It was used for travelling shows and one big hall and party each year at which each person was charged $1/2 to raise money for prizes at the annual country fair.

10. When parties, dances, etc. were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? Not usually, just those who liked to.

How were babies and small children provided for? A woman took turns looking after them.

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? Lots of blankets were put on them and they were tied up.

11. What card games were popular in the early days? None at our house had a home made pool table.

Was there card playing for a prize? No

What dances were popular? Don't remember the names. On the red river "The River jig most popular.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. No disagreements. Some Methodists did not dance & did not go to dancing parties. These were very few.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain. There was hardly any card playing. I never saw any that started after 1900.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, poinsettias, etc.) Give dates.

In 1884-85-86 in a school house near our old farm district. The schools were used for evening classes by local pupils and for school support and land grant time.

It was built in the village or town, or was it a country hall in a village? To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for local meetings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings and make use of the hall in town for all gatherings, etc.? If so, why?)

10. What parties did you attend? Did you attend parties at these parties? How were babies and small children provided for? How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days? How did you play them?

Was there card playing for a prize? How much money was won?

What dances were popular? What music was played?

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Card playing started after 1900.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank," do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? 

There were in Indian Head some people who felt themselves better than others and just called amongst themselves.

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? no

Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

The most of the parties in the village had their regular calling days after 1900.

About the middle of the winter of 1900 Bill Motherwell (so our dear friend said) came to the Homestead in the snowstorm of December 27th and 28th. He had been away from the farm for several weeks, and his mother was very anxious about him. They had started out early in the morning for Indiana, where they had heard there was a good market for their horses. After several days' travel they had arrived at their destination, but instead of finding work, they found themselves in a difficult situation. They had no money and no place to stay. They decided to return home, but before they could do so, they were arrested by the police for vagrancy. They were taken to court and sentenced to six months in prison. They appealed to the courts, but their appeals were denied. They were finally released after serving their sentence.

The farmers were very concerned about their situation, and they decided to form an association to help them. They met with Mr. Williams, Mr. Dayman, Mr. Miller, Mr. Indian Head, Mr. Baldwin, John Miller, and others to discuss their problems. They agreed to work together and to find solutions to their difficulties. All the farmers were willing to help each other, and they worked hard to improve their situation.

Premier Roblin of Manitoba and Premier Haultain of the North West Territories were to hold a meeting at Brandon House on Dec. 18th, 1907 to discuss co-operative organization or part of it in the northern part of Manitoba.

A meeting of the farmers was arranged to take place after this and they organized the Territorial Grain Growers Association. Mothurnell was elected Provincial president and further provincial officers were elected president Miller secretary Mothurnell treasurer John Miller recording clerk.

On the invitation of Mr. Mothurnell he was managing director and accepted the position of Provincial Secretary.

Manitoba and the Manitoba Grain Growers Association were formed.

Note when the provinces of Saskatchewan and Alberta were formed a Grain Growers Association was formed in each.

Mothurnell resigned as president and became minister of Agriculture.
Premier Roblin of Manitoba and Premier Macdonald of the North West Territories were to hold a meeting at Brandon House on May 18th, 1907 to discuss co-operative associations or part of it in the rural part of Manitoba.

A meeting of the farmers was arranged to take place after this and they organized the Provincial Grain Growers Association. Mothurnell was elected Provincial President and further Provincial Secretary, Miller was elected Provincial Secretary, and John Maclean was elected Managing Director.

On the invitation of Mr. Maclean, Manitoba and the Manitoba Grain Growers Association met in Brandon, Manitoba and Alberta were formed a Grain Growers Association was formed in each.

Mothurnell resigned as Provincial Secretary of Agriculture and became Minister of Agriculture.
